channel.title: Visual Basic - mouse_event API (windows)
channel.description:
I'm using the mouse_event API from the user32 dll to simulate a mouseclick. [code]Declare Sub mouse_event Lib "User32" (ByVal dwFlags As Long, ByVal dx As Long, ByVal dy As Long, ByVal cButtons As Long, ByVal dwExtraInfo As Long)[/code]
To simulate the click: [code]mouse_event(&H2, 0, 0, 0, 0) mouse_event(&H4, 0, 0, 0, 0)[/code]
But I don't quite understand the &H2 and &H4. I know the &H2 means left mouse down and &H4 means left mouse up.
I think those values get written somewhere in the memory, get read by windows --> Click.
Am I right?
Can someone explain this further?
Thank you (:

item.title: Visual Basic - mouse_event API (windows)
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:10, topic:429248”]Just because the BASIC notation predates C, doesn’t make it superior.[/quote]who said anything about notation superiority, i merely said that there’s no normal way. besides, it’s a few characters that differs between languages… srsly who gives a fuck

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic - mouse_event API (windows)
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:11, topic:429248”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=531937.msg3889184#msg3889184 date=1326689040]
Just because the BASIC notation predates C, doesn’t make it superior.
[/quote]

With all the languages I’ve dealt with I have never seen anything other than 0x notation so it was shocking. Cool to learn something new.[/quote]

Same. I’ve seen \x before and 0x before, and seen h suffixed in ASM, but never &H as a prefix.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Basic - mouse_event API (windows)
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote="_s, post:8, topic:429248"][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=531937.msg3888415#msg3888415 date=1326655424]

from reading the docs of mouse_event &H2 is just hexadecimal two so 0x0002 which is also MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN, &H4 is 0x0004 hence MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP

therefore

&H1 - MOUSEEVENTF_MOVE
&H2 - MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTDOWN,
&H4 - MOUSEEVENTF_LEFTUP
&H20 - MOUSEEVENTF_MIDDLEDOWN
&H40 - MOUSEEVENTF_MIDDLEUP
and so on, just convert the 0x notation hexadecimals from the docs to the &H notation used in Visual Basic

They couldn’t just use the normal notation…
[/quote]there is no normal notation for hexadecimal numbers, C family languages use 0x notation (0xff), many BASIC dialects use the &H (&HFF), some assemblers use a h suffix (ffh), most lisps use #x notatation (#xff). ‘normal’ notation in your limited arsenal of languages just happens to be C hexadecimal notation, when i think you’ll find that original BASIC notation actually predates C’s anyway.[/quote]

didn’t know that. thanks for the clarification.

Read full topic

&H20 - MOUSEEVENTF_MIDDLEDOWN

[/quote]

They couldn’t just use the normal notation…[/quote]there is no normal notation for hexadecimal numbers, C family languages use 0x notation (0xff), many BASIC dialects use the &H (&HFF), some assemblers use a h suffix (ffh), most lisps use #x notatation (#xff). ‘normal’ notation in your limited arsenal of languages just happens to be C hexadecimal notation, when i think you’ll find that original BASIC notation actually predates C’s anyway.

To simulate the click:

mouse_event(&H2, 0, 0, 0, 0) mouse_event(&H4, 0, 0, 0, 0)
